claim: Archaeologists spend most of their time excavating historical sites.

supporting.text: Archaeologists conduct excavations to uncover and study artifacts, structures, and other physical remains, which is a core part of their fieldwork.

attacks.text: Archaeologists conduct excavations to uncover and study artifacts, structures, and other physical remains, which is a core part of their fieldwork.
Excavations are only a small part of an archaeologist's work, as they also spend significant time on lab analysis, documentation, and academic research.
Fieldwork, including excavations, is often seasonal and limited by funding, weather, and permits, reducing the actual time spent digging.
Many archaeologists specialize in areas like digital archaeology or museum curation, which require little to no excavation work.
Excavations are destructive, so archaeologists prioritize non-invasive methods like surveys and remote sensing when possible.

supporting.text: Excavations are time-intensive due to the need for careful documentation, preservation, and analysis of findings, often requiring months or years at a single site.

attacks.text: Excavations are time-intensive due to the need for careful documentation, preservation, and analysis of findings, often requiring months or years at a single site.
Many archaeologists focus on lab-based analysis, remote sensing, or archival research rather than fieldwork, reducing time spent on excavations.
Even non-excavation work often supports or follows excavations, making them a central part of archaeological practice.
Some excavations are rapid rescue operations due to construction or erosion threats, not prolonged research projects.

supporting.text: Many archaeologists also engage in laboratory analysis, archival research, and academic writing, which can take up significant portions of their time.

attacks.text: Many archaeologists also engage in laboratory analysis, archival research, and academic writing, which can take up significant portions of their time.
Fieldwork and excavation remain the most time-consuming activities for archaeologists, as they require extensive planning, logistics, and on-site work.
Even during fieldwork, much of the time is spent on documentation, surveying, and preliminary analysis rather than actual excavation.
Public perception and media portrayals often overemphasize excavation, leading to a skewed understanding of archaeologists' actual work distribution.
Specialized subfields like experimental archaeology or digital archaeology may involve little to no excavation work at all.

supporting.text: Fieldwork is seasonal in many regions, limiting excavation periods and requiring archaeologists to focus on other tasks outside of digging seasons.

attacks.text: Fieldwork is seasonal in many regions, limiting excavation periods and requiring archaeologists to focus on other tasks outside of digging seasons.
Many archaeological projects are conducted in regions with year-round fieldwork potential, allowing continuous excavation.
Even in regions with year-round fieldwork, logistical constraints like funding and permits often limit excavation time.
Excavation is only one part of archaeology; lab analysis, documentation, and publication require significant time regardless of fieldwork season.

supporting.text: Modern archaeology increasingly relies on non-invasive techniques like remote sensing and geophysical surveys, reducing the need for extensive excavation.

attacks.text: Modern archaeology increasingly relies on non-invasive techniques like remote sensing and geophysical surveys, reducing the need for extensive excavation.
Excavation is still essential for obtaining direct physical evidence and artifacts that non-invasive methods cannot provide.
Non-invasive techniques often require subsequent excavation to verify findings, meaning excavation remains a significant part of archaeological work.
Many archaeological projects, especially in regions with limited funding, still rely heavily on traditional excavation due to lack of access to advanced technology.
Even with funding, some sites (e.g., urban or densely layered ones) require excavation because non-invasive methods struggle with complex stratigraphy.

supporting.text: Grant funding and logistical constraints often limit the frequency and duration of excavation projects, making them a smaller part of an archaeologist's career.

attacks.text: Grant funding and logistical constraints often limit the frequency and duration of excavation projects, making them a smaller part of an archaeologist's career.
Many archaeologists work in academic or research institutions where excavation is a primary activity, supported by continuous funding.
Even in academic settings, excavation is seasonal and requires extensive pre- and post-excavation work, reducing actual digging time.
Field schools and training programs ensure that excavation remains a core activity for many archaeologists, regardless of funding constraints.
Field schools are short-term and often not representative of the daily work of professional archaeologists.
